This is exactly like the arguments for the self-driving cars go. For those who support it, they point out how it just needs to make LESS mistakes, and that decreases the car accident deaths and injuries significantly. For those who oppose it, they mostly boil down to gut rejection that goes along the line of: "So you think machines can replace human? You think they are perfect, and makes no mistakes?"
People want perfect solutions, but the history proves that when the new technology is introduced, it has shortcomings that only hindsight shows, but the technology was advanced nonetheless because it was tested. Without actually putting on the field, nothing can be learned for 100% accuracy. Even then, there is always some sort of hindsight left to be discovered.
This is a ugly truth no one wants to talk about, and neither myself, honestly. But even after knowing all these, you can still vote if you live under democracy, to bring about temporary or permanent changes that suits your decision. Innovations, and more importantly science, has been historically "advanced" when the previous generation died and could no longer appeal to their own authorities. New ideas only became accepted and verified by others when the new generation was willing to accept new ideas, when proven true. Democracy has a lot of shortcomings, but one undeniable fact is that it's a effective tool to overcome authorities who believe otherwise. Of course, for better or worse. If you don't vote, you might as well as consider your voting right void.

The arguments made by those that don't understand nuclear physics or radiation even boils down to pointing the finger at Chernobyl and Two Mile Island, or even Fukushima.

Let me give a good counter to arguments that claim the technology is too dangerous.

Look at air travel. Its widespread, very safe, and efficient. Air travel however in the 1960s, 70s and even 80s, was much less safe. Mid air collisions for example had a much higher percentage of occurring. Aircraft with cut corners on maintenence protocol or redundancy failures (such as no shutoff valves for hydraulic lines), as well as failures in airport security (such as the Phillipines Airlines bombing in the 90s).

I can easily point to crashes such as the Tenerife Disaster, TWA 800, the United Airlines Sioux Falls crash, the Grand Canyon midair collision, the American Airlines DC-10 crash at O'Hare, and claim just by looking at horrific events such as those that, air travel is unsafe and that we should go back to sea travel or car travel.

But guess what? Air travel has learned, with failsafe systems, layered redundancies, higher tech ATC, updated guidelines and automated warning systems have all made air travel as common, safe, cheap, and efficient as it is now.

Same argument applies for nuclear. Every major nuclear power incident constantly looked at (Chernobyl, Two Mile Island, Fukushima) all utilized less safe and less efficient light water reactors, utilizing Uranium as fuel.

As we move into the future however, there are MANY different options for Nuclear Fission that make it ultimately, A VERY GOOD CHOICE to aid transitions into renewable and clean electricity.

Examples include Thorium based fission, pressurized heavy water reactors, etc.

Also, long lived nuclear waste is not that big a deal, in France it is separated from U238 (96% of the waste), which can be used in Fast neutron reactors, meaning we essentially have lots of U238 to run our future reactors, so it can't be considered as waste. The rest is put in stainless steel containers, trapped in solid balls of glass so that it can't escape, and the radioactivity of this will decrease significantly over the course of the life of the container, which is 10 000 years. After that, the radioactivity will anyway be lower than regular U238 which can be found anywhere, so.... And when buried in these tanks, the radioactivity does not escape the tanks.

All in all, after 40 years of having 70% of its electricity from nuclear power, France only has 3 500 cubic meters of said waste, or 10 000 tonnes. That would fit in an olympic swimming pool, and that's it. Meanwhile, windmill blades, solar panels, coal and gas release vastly greater amoutns of waste, which, albeit non radioactive, is not safely stored like nuclear waste is, and is essentially lying around or buried, or emitted into the atmosphere. It's estimated that we will have to deal with decommissioning 600 000 tonnes of windmill blades worldwide per year starting 2025, and millions of tonnes of solar panels and batteries. Now, that's what I call a green revolution.

The accident in Japan at Fukushima Daiichi in March 2011 followed a major earthquake and tsunami. The tsunami flooded out the power supply and cooling systems of three power reactors, causing them to melt down and explode, breaching their confinement. Although 154,000 Japanese citizens were evacuated from a 12-mile exclusion zone around the power station, radiation exposure beyond the station grounds was limited. According to the report submitted to the International Atomic Energy Agency in June 2011:

“No harmful health effects were found in 195,345 residents living in the vicinity of the plant who were screened by the end of May 2011. All the 1,080 children tested for thyroid gland exposure showed results within safe limits. By December, government health checks of some 1,700 residents who were evacuated from three municipalities showed that two-thirds received an external radiation dose within the normal international limit of 1 mSv/year, 98 percent were below 5 mSv/year, and 10 people were exposed to more than 10 mSv… [There] was no major public exposure, let alone deaths from radiation.”
Nuclear waste disposal, although a continuing political problem in the U.S., is not any longer a technological problem. Most U.S. spent fuel, more than 90 percent of which could be recycled to extend nuclear power production by hundreds of years, is stored at present safely in impenetrable concrete-and-steel dry casks on the grounds of operating reactors, its radiation slowly declining.

This is ridiculous. First nuclear waste doesnt exist. Waste itself doesnt exist. Feces is considered waste but its also used as a fertilizer. So is eating food a waste? Nuclear byproduct, not waste, is only partially used. Over 90% of that byproduct is not used. 99% of uranium is not used, and 100% of thorium is not used. So that argument is moot. Nuclear waste cant be an issue if it doesnt exist.
Second, the high cost of nuclear is because we build giant solid fueled heat engines, when instead we should be building small modular fission fragment reactors. A fission fragment reactor would be 1/20th the size for the same power output. If you add a 200 kilowatt thermal duel fluid reactor then you can recycle unused byproduct on site while also breeding new fuel as you go. This design would let us power the entire world while also having nuclear produce all transport fuels for over 1 million years. Mixed with renewables and you have much longer.
Third issue is catastrophy. Every single nuclear issue is a result of bad engineering. You cannot make gigantic high temperature high pressure reactors and not expect issues. This has nothing to do with nuclear. High temperature + high pressure + continuous operation + gigantic structures = unseen outcomes. The 2 reactors I told you about above are both atmospheric pressure. 1 is around 500F and the other is around 1500F.
A fission fragment reactor built right could power my subcompact kia soul with shielding included and weigh about 500 pounds including the small coolant system. Small because 90% of its energy is turned into electricity. All current nuclear reactors convert 100% of their energy into heat.

They make nuclear power plants now that contain fuel that physically can't break down and is far more efficient than standard core reactors. Just look up "nuclear power" on YouTube and there are multiple videos. It's actually really interesting.

Btw, those who are wondering what happened in 1957: The Kyshtym desaster, or the Mayak incident, one of the best kept secrets of Soviet times. And the reason why the north of Siberia (or rather: asian Russia) is pretty much unpopulated, due to being full of radiation. And the sad thing is, until today Mayak is still running, despite several incidents happening again and again. Anyone heard news of a sudden rise of radiation in 2017? Guess where it came from.

One other downside of nuclear energy is the process to produce nuclear fuel.  The process of converting uranium ore into nuclear fuel is extremely toxic, requiring a vast amount of sulfuric acid, manganese dioxide, sodium hydroxide, and ammonium nitrate, and the process creates quite a bit of highly toxic byproducts such as radon gas and arsenic.  Most of the waste product is stored in artificial lakes called impoundments, and every uranium mine and processing facility leaves behind thousands of metric tons of very deadly toxic and radioactive waste ponds that are left to evaporate or leech into the water table.  Nuclear power is clean, making nuclear fuel is VERY dirty.

Sorry that this video repeats the standard myths about nuclear. These three statements are only slightly true but we never get to that point and discuss the real issues. No one has ever made a nuclear bomb from power reactor plutonium. hypothetically it is possible but the materials are hardly 'just lying around'. Yes there have been a few reactor accidents but compared to other energy and other industrial accidents their impacts have been very small. There is no real indication that even the worst accident in Ukraine has contaminated the area 'so that no one can live there for decades' There are people who have lived inside of the exclusion zone for more than thirty years without showing any adverse health effects from their exposure. Nuclear waste is not dangerous for 10s of thousands of years! most of nuclear waste is dangerous in a few hundred years and the stuff that last longer isn't really that dangerous. The stuff that is most dangerous decays quickly and releases a large amount of energy over a short period of time. If it decays away over a long time it isn't releasing very much energy in a given amount of time and so it is not as dangerous. If we do our research we find that these statements are not well supported by fact but they have been repeated so often that many people take them as fact without any thought. Let think more about the facts and then when you understand what is really fact and myth then you can decide if you like nuclear power.

Yeah, none of these hold up. First off, i think we need to stop worrying about nuclear proliferation. There have only been two bombs ever dropped on people and despite several other countries (including North Korea which never had nuclear reactors) getting nuclear weapons, they haven’t ever used them. Everyone is deterred by self preservation because if they would be taken out if they even tried. And we have to face the fact that getting what you need to make a nuclear bomb is actually quite easy and all the information you need is available online for free. If a kid in the 80’s can build a function nuclear reactor in his backyard, how easy do you think it is for someone today to build a nuclear weapon? Fact is we can’t stop them, we can only detour them, and nuclear reactors have actually caused many countries to dismantle their nuclear weapons to use for fuel.

As for the waste problem, there are several solutions to this. The reprocessing you said we can’t do yet we actually can do in high power reactors. You also have the nuclear pebble solution which significantly reduces the waste and eliminates the possibility of meltdown as they can simply design a heat plug at the bottom that will melt if the reactor gets too hot emptying out the reactor without any actions required by operators. We can make reactors that can go unsupervised now.

As for the accidents, those have all been from old reactors that were entirely avoidable if they had admired to protocol. Chernobyl was gross negligence, and Fukushima was outdated technology that had should have been updated but wasn’t. In fact, there was a nearby power plant that’s didn’t melt down because it was newer. Also keep in mind Fukushima caused no deaths, aside from the botched evacuation which killed over 100,000. 1. It is certainly possible to build nuclear reactors while minimizing nuclear proliferation. Since the Cold War, the number of nuclear weapons in the US and in the world has decreased significantly (although the number of nuclear reactors has also dropped - but that needn't be the case!). More to the point, if you're concerned about other countries using nuclear fuel for weapons, as other commenters pointed out, give them Thorium. Thorium reactors don't produce Plutonium and are desirable for other reasons. (I also think that the video exaggerates our inability to tell if other countries are building weapons; we have ways of gaining intelligence).
2. First, we are good at storing nuclear waste and there's not much of it. All of the nuclear waste we have ever produced could fit on an area the size of a football field, with negligible risk of an accident if cared for properly. Further, newer designs for reactors would produce waste that could be reused entirely. And reactors could be kept offshore to further security.
3. Nuclear energy causes less deaths per unit power produced than any major energy source by far! On a par with wind and solar. (Look it up, it's baffling that most people don't know this.) And while the notable past accidents are truly terrifying, they were primarily the result of extraordinary negligence. Reactors of the future will merit improved design and safety measures. Further, coal and natural gas kill millions every year in the form of pollution.

In light of the Chernobyl series, that was riddled with scientific inaccuracies, this debate is becoming even more fueled. If you're a nuclear operator or engineer, these arguments and shenanigans will thoroughly annoy you.


1. Reactor Technology and understanding helped create nuclear weapons, but those that have ability to create them and already have them don't need nuclear reactor plants to do so. Nuclear Reactor Plants aren't going to give nuclear weapons to people that don't already have them, so this "nuclear proliferation" argument is the most tedious and trivial point that anti-nuclear activists raise. The amount of resources and technological access that one would need in order to create a bomb from a low-enriched reactor plant is like finding a unicorn. Let's take Iran for example and the US' Nuclear deal. Iran was limited to a set amount of centrifuges, and very inefficient ones too. They're also bound to not exceed 3.67% enrichment, which is consistent with every other commercial reactor plant in the world, at 3-5% enrichment. HIGH enriched uranium, on the order of 90%+ is nuclear weapons material. Also, all of their NSF is shipped OUT of the country. This is heavily monitored and regulated by the IAEA. The IAEA does this with a multitude of countries that people don't want to have nuclear weapons (as if the world doesn't already have enough to cause humanity's destruction).


The IAEA inspections act as an alert system providing a warning of the possible diversion of nuclear material from peaceful activities. The system relies on;
Material Accountability – tracking all inward and outward transfers and the flow of materials in any nuclear facility. This includes sampling and analysis of nuclear material, on-site inspections, review and verification of operating records.
Physical Security – restricting access to nuclear materials at the site of use.
Containment and Surveillance – use of seals, automatic cameras and other instruments to detect unreported movement or tampering with nuclear materials, as well as spot checks on-site.

To this date, we don't have nuclear proliferation occurring (well, because of nuclear power). 

2. Spent Nuclear Fuel is quite literally the ONLY waste that is meticulously maintained. Never once has it hurt anyone, and it never will. Tell me, what are the plans for solar waste and the toxic elements, like cadmium, that don't decay? That can't be used in reprocessing? Also, we do have reactor designs for reprocessing, and France is a good example of this. It is quite perfectly within the scope of our scientific capabilities, but democratic administrations oppose this legislation. It's also worthy to point out of little waste there actually is. It is effectively nonexistent. The "SNF could be use for proliferation" is merely a part of point 1, not 2. Countries that have this technological capability already have nuclear weapons, so it's a red herring to even bring up. A "milligram" can kill you.. okay, show me a single person in the past 70 years that has died form the small amount of nuclear waste that is apparently so plentiful? Oh, wait, that's right.. not a single person. And reprocessing IS a good idea in regards to Germany. You know what is ironic in this context? They decommissioned all of their nuclear plants, went "renewable," and ended up with higher electricity costs and CO2 emissions because of this, and now rely on natural gas to fill the void that nuclear left. Mhm, strange, wouldn't you say? The "hundreds of thousands of tons of waste" is, again, misleading like most of this video. Uranium is EXTREMELY dense, and so are a lot of nuclear byproducts of fission. It weighs a lot, but comparable to the amount of room it takes up, it is considerably less than you would think. For the US, it's about the dimensions of a football field that is 15 meters deep. That is negligible. Now, imagine if we also had reprocessing and the anti-nuclear nutcases weren't so patently absurd about opposing this legislation. 
3. Accidents and Disasters....


Well, look no further than shear data and statistical probability. If you are irrationally scared of nuclear incidents, of which only one in 6 decades (Chernobyl) resulted in the deaths of humans, but you are totally content on flying planes, you are a nutcase. No, there haven't been "7 Major Accidents." That's a lie. Only THREE are considered major accidents: TMI, Fukushima, and Chernobyl.. TMI, nothing ended up even happening, and the other 4 you listed were even less of an impact. These 3 are the only ones that suffered considerable core damage, and this point is a good example of why it is annoying listening to individuals who have no professional background in this industry. Realistically, only 2 are of any major concern, as nothing even happened with TMI, leaving just fukushima and chernobyl. "Four of them released significant reactivity into the environment." Two*.. the word you're looking for is two*. While many claimed that lands were "unfit for human habitation," a lot of these efforts were just completely bananas. Japan is PERFECTLY fine to inhabit in the relative vicinity of the reactor plant. What you're claiming is just an utter lie and pure sci-fi. Even the local marine life is doing just fine, and Ukraine was never uninhabitable, ever. Only the immediate area, and to assert that it was for "decades," again, is another lie. This just isn't true. You're propagating fear-mongering myths of the extent of radiation. How people reacted is NOT indicative of what was actually true or how they should have treated the situation. For example, the mass evacuation effort at Fukushima made things MUCH worse. Some ionizing radiation from a reactor plant isn't going to make countries uninhabitable. That is just fucking science fiction, dude. Honestly, did you guys consult experts for this video? "The death toll was probably in the thousands." NO, NO IT WASN'T. Where are you getting research? You should know this isn't true if you have read anything from the UN in this century. It's on the order of a few hundred, were the vast majority of deaths occurred from first responders. Chernobyl is credited by the UN as being responsible for about a quarter of the thyroid cancer cases, and no other cancer. They reported 20,000 cases, leaving about 5000 cases of thyroid cancer attributed to Chernobyl. Thyroid cancer has a 1% mortality rate.. yes, abut 50, maybe 100, maybe less, died from cancer as a result from chernobyl, and a couple hundred from radiation sickness, and a few from fire and one from rubble. You can't even break 500 with the most recent reports, let alone "in the thousands." It's like you're so careless with the data you're gathering, that you're taking it from reports in the 80s or early 90s.

Also, when you suggest "different reactor types having a disaster every 30 years or so" is, again, bull shit. What happened at Fukushima was entirely different than Chernobyl, and the consequences were too. NO ONE died at Fukushima as a result of radiation. NONE. Every experience is also a valuable learning lesson, especially as reactors gets more advanced. You also have to remember, only Chernobyl and Fukushima are the real offenders here when it comes to significant core damage and the release of radioactive material. Fukushima was hit by a 9.0 fucking earthquake and tsunami, and even then, the US' NRC criticized their plant design and said it could have been avoided, which it could have by merely elevating diesel generators. Chernobyl, if you understand the physics, cann't happen with other reactor designs. It is unique to the RBMK-1000 reactor because it has a positive reactivity coefficient, and even then, they had to DELIBERATELY disable emergency cooling, bypass the scram, and disable other redundancies, as well as go below the minimum requirement of rods that are supposed to left in the core. That reactor couldn't even be licensed in the US, and reactor operators here wouldn't be able to disable safety equipment like that on a whim. The RBMK was also not a LWR, and it had a graphite moderator with NO containment vessel. Despite the poor regulations, incompetent operators that maliciously disabled safety features, and just utter stupidity, the situation could have been avoided if they merely installed a containment vessel, like they do with every other reactor in the world. We have reinforced steel with several feet of concrete here in the US. The design flaws were just the cherry on top for Chernobyl, and if one were to replicate that day perfectly with their own RBMK-1000 reactor, ALL of it could have been avoided form releasing radioactive material into the environment if they just had a damn containment vessel.

HOWEVER, despite these, nuclear still is statistically the safest with the lowest mortality rate, deaths/Kwh, and there are energy disasters that have been FAR worse that no one seems to talk nor care about, like the Banqaio Dam collapse in China that killed 200.000 people and displace 11 million from their homes. I guarantee 99.9% of the population has never even heard of this. This video is largely fear-mongering BS.

1. Without nuclear weapons, countries and peoples wanting war will find other ways to develop weapons of mass destruction. Chemical weapons, biological weapons, and don't forget about good old gunpowder based weapons.

2. Fossil fuels release a lot more radioactive material into the air than nuclear power, not to mention the millions of tonnes of noxious soot and excess carbon dioxide. These can't be safely buried like nuclear waste - they are released into the air, blanketing certain areas in pollution, shortening lives, and contributing to global warming and massive environmental damage. Yeah, it's unfortunate that spent nuclear waste has to be buried somewhere, but at least it's not in the air all around us.

3. One major accident every 30 years? There are fossil fuel based disasters a lot more often than every 30 years - try multiple times a year. Mining accidents, plant explosions, etc. Globally, coal has a death rate over 1,000 TIMES that of nuclear power per unit of power produced. Oil is at 500 times the death rate of nuclear per unit of power produced. Even natural gas's death rate is 44 times that of nuclear per unit of power produced. Biomass's death rate is at over 250 times that of the same unit of nuclear power. Need I say more? Even solar and wind power have worse death rates than nuclear (though still very low). Of those three major incidents? One was very early in the history of nuclear power, another was a poorly designed reactor (that is still very outdated), and the other was caused by a massive earthquake that would have probably destroyed a fossil fuel plant as well.

I like to show a video such as this and then provide a transcript to go along with questions to assist students. It is a simple and effective accommodation. Here is a corrected and usable transcript:

3 REASONS WHY NUCLEAR ENERGY IS TERRIBLE (PART 2/3)

Three reasons why we should stop using nuclear energy:


1. Nuclear weapons proliferation. Nuclear technology made a violent entrance onto the world stage just one year after the world's first-ever nuclear test explosion in 1944. Two large cities were destroyed by just two, single bombs. After that, reactor technology slowly evolved as a means of generating electricity, but it's always been intimately connected with nuclear weapons technology. It's nearly impossible to develop nuclear weapons without access to reactor technology. In fact, the nuclear non-proliferation treaty serves the purpose of spreading nuclear reactor technology without spreading nuclear weapons; with limited success. In 40 years, five countries have developed their own weapons with the help of reactor technology. The fact of the matter is that it can be very hard to distinguish a covert nuclear weapons program from the peaceful use of nuclear energy. In the 1970s, the big nuclear powers were happily selling peaceful technology to smaller countries which then developed weapons of their own. The road to deadly nuclear weapons is always paved with peaceful reactors.



2. Nuclear waste and pollution. Spent nuclear fuel is not only radioactive, but also contains extremely poisonous chemical elements like plutonium. It loses its harmfulness only slowly over several tens of thousands of years. And there is also a process called reprocessing which means the extraction of plutonium from spent nuclear fuel. It can be used for two purposes: to build nuclear weapons or to use it as new fuel, but hardly any of it is used as fuel because we don't have the right kind of reactors for that. A milligram will kill you, a few kilograms make an atomic bomb, and even an inconspicuous country like Germany, literally has tons of the stuff just lying around because reprocessing sounded like a good idea decades ago. And where will all the waste go? After dumping it into the ocean was forbidden, we've tried to bury it, but we can't find a place where it will definitely stay secure for tens of thousands of years. Over 30 countries operate nearly 400 reactors managing several hundred thousands of tons of nuclear waste and only one is currently serious about opening a permanent civilian waste storage: tiny Finland.



3. Accidents and disasters. Over sixty years of nuclear power usage there have been seven major accidents in reactors or facilities dealing with nuclear waste. Three of those were mostly contained, but four of them released significant amounts of radioactivity into the environment. In 1957, 1987, and 2011, large areas of land in Russia, Ukraine, and Japan, were rendered unfit for human habitation for decades to come. The number of deaths is highly disputed, but probably lies in the thousands. These disasters happened with nuclear reactors of very different types, in very different countries, and several decades apart. Looking at the numbers we may as well ask ourselves: are 10% of the world's energy supply worth a devastating disaster every 30 years? Would 30% be worth another Fukushima or Chernobyl somewhere on earth every 10 years? What area would have to be contaminated so we say “no more?” Where is the line? So, should we use nuclear energy? The risks may outweigh the benefits and maybe we should stop looking into this direction and drop this technology for good.

Another con is, the economics are not sound, in that the profit from nuclear energy goes to large corporations, but the cost of waste storage and the dismantling of discontinued sites and disaster response is very often taken out off the tax payers pocket.

These operations often come at the expense of the health and lives of workers and local residents in and near Uranium mining, power plant operation, and waste management.

Finally, use of nuclear energy often has a detrimental effect on political culture and transparency, leading to secret dealings, executive orders, and anti-democratic state-of-emergency clauses being introduced.

The Fukushima reactor failure was caused mainly by an external catastrophe rather than a faulty handling of nuclear reactors.

The three most well known nuclear accidents were at Three Mile Island, Chernobyl, and Fukushima. The Three Mile Island incident didn't kill anyone. The Fukushima incident happened entirely due to an earthquake (if you're not building a nuclear plant near a fault zone, you can entirely discount this incident) and no more than two deaths can be attributed to it. As for Chernobyl, up to 64 deaths can be attributed to it, making it the deadliest nuclear disaster to date (the next deadliest disaster only killed 4 people).


Each of these three disasters happened with generation II reactors, the first generation to be commercially viable (generation I was experimental). Generation III and generation IV reactors have the potential to produce the same amount of power with less uranium. Generation IV reactors may be able to use uranium with 100-300 times more efficiency, making nuclear incidents all the less likely. And that's just with uranium. Thorium power has many advantages over uranium power. In fact, according to its supporters, there is enough thorium in the US to sustain current electricity levels for over a millennia.

Molten salt thorium reactors can be designed in such a way that the U-232 content is so high that the neutron background from spontaneous fission is so high that no implosion assembly can overcome predetonation, aand weapons could yield no more than 0.5kt. Moreover sealed modular reactors of this type can be made very tamper resistant. And the small amount of uranium salts left once the reactor is decommissioned can be handled by specialist facilities under International Atomic Energy Agency inspection, ensuring the fuel isn't used for tactical weapons.

Reasons a uranium-plutonium fuel cycle is terrible*. Thorium reactors (molten salt reactors) lack almost all the problems that uranium reactors have. Thorium can't be easily weaponized so they don't contribute to proliferation. You have to constantly ADD heat rather than maintain cooling to keep a reaction going, so you don't have the risk of meltdowns (uranium reactor containment domes explode and release radiation because the water used to cool it evaporates too much and produces pressure until a critical failure-- no water cooling is necessary for MSRs). Thorium doesn't produce huge amounts of horribly dangerous waste. Thorium is also multiple times more efficient and more plentiful on Earth than uranium. Literally the only reason we chose to pursue uranium power is because it was more weaponizable, and once the first generation of uranium-plutonium fuel cycle reactors were built, no energy corporation wanted to be the first to invest in replacing their infrastructure, which is why we still use dangerous reactors from the 70s (yes, believe it or not, in many ways capitalism HOLDS BACK innovation and technological progress). But the foundational research has already been done 40-50 years ago.

We could easily make the obvious choice to switch over if we had the means to collectively invest based on what would benefit society and humanity rather than what will maintain and maximize profit next quarter. In countries like India they are already pursuing thorium power, a huge advantage and benefit moving into the mid 21st century. But yeah; I just hate to see ALL nuclear power demonized as if it's all as terrible as what we have now. I would like to see Green Parties and other left-wing and social ecological institutions push to revamp our nuclear power with thorium, both for safety and efficiency. Maybe it can be phased out altogether one day, but in the meantime it'd BE A HUGE step forward. The fact that almost no one has heard of thorium energy demonstrates the power of the energy lobbies. It was basically killed just like the electric car.

1) Unrelated. Nuclear weapons can be developed without using nuclear energy. Despite the video's claim to the contrary, nuclear weapons do not require a reactor for pre-development (which the video starts off by noting, before reversing itself). Also see: Genie/Bottle.

2) Finland is hardly tiny, having more land mass than most other nations on the planet, most of which is uninhabited and distant - key necessities for nuclear waste disposal. Finland, by itself, could in fact store the entire planet's nuclear waste for the foreseeable future with space to spare, and that's assuming we never develop the technology necessary to recycle or render waste inert. This would of course amount to a major economic boon to Finland, which is why they are even considering it.

3) All of the nuclear accidents worldwide to date, put together, have had less ecological impact that just ONE related to fossil fuels: the California Oil Flood. We haven't abandoned fossil fuels over things like the Exxon Valdez, why would we abandon nuclear power over Chernobyl?

@Kurzgesagt, great and informative video! However, the only thing I found was that you guys failed to mention thermal pollution. It is a large problem for nuclear energy plants- fission creates a lot of heat (obviously, this is needed to convert water to steam and turn the turbine, etc.). Water is used in nuclear energy plants to avoid the plant being overheated, but in the process “picks up” the heat. This water used to be directly piped back into local ponds, which killed tons of fish and other aquatic organisms. Because thermal pollution is really hard to detect (bordering on impossible), we didn’t even know why nearby fish were dying for many, many years. Today, holding ponds can be created and used to literally hold the hot water until it cools, but of course this solution isn’t perfect. Ultimately, the point here is that I think you guys did a fantastic job as regards the more well-known risks of nuclear energy, but you may have accidentally neglected to talk about another type of pollution that, while not as well known, can be devastating.

1) As for weapons, you'll never be able to stop that. That's like saying that the industrial revolution was bad, because modern guns, or the Bronze age was bad, because blades.

2) The waste is a genuine negative right now, but, as you mentioned, it's something that can be alleviated by researching into better recycling methods. It's not like solar or wind, where we hope we can make it more efficient by researching it. In the case of nuclear waste, we already know there is a solution - we just need to perfect the methods - and, if we stock up too much waste it the meantime, we could just launch a rocket full of it into deep space.

3) Finally, the disasters. They are far and few between, and are easily fixable. They were cause by two things:
- poor handling - fixed with better protocol, which comes naturally with wider adoption
- natural disasters - easily fixed with better planing and more advanced structuring (again, the adoption).

I realize you wanted to approach this topic neutrally, but the benefits clearly outweigh the risks. This shouldn't even be a discussion. The only reason nuclear energy is not as successful as it could be, is because of paranoia. If we ever want to advance, people will have to get over it.

EDIT: Since writing this, I have discovered that we have reactors that make use of waste already, so waste isn't even an issue. They are used heavily in France.

The biggest problem with this video is that it refers specifically to the historically dangerous Light Water Reactors as generic "nuclear energy" and not to the many variations now being considered, with the Molten Salt Reactors having none of the problems mentioned. LWR has solid fuel, water cooled, high pressure and can melt down and cause an accident, and only burns 3% of the fuel meaning it needs reprocessing and storage. MSR is liquid fuel, not water cooled, at ambient pressure and cannot melt down, and burns nearly 100% of its fuel and does not need reprocessing or storage. In fact MSR is the answer to burning the existing stored nuclear waste. It is a common misconception to lump all nuclear reactor types together, but would have been much more informative if the specific problems with each type were explained. Some people are aware that Thorium can be used in a reactor but do not realise that it is the reactor technology that is the problem/solution, not the fuel. It should be noted that the MSR was shown to be a viable working reactor in the 1950s, and that China and other countries are now reopening this technology to make Gen IV nuclear reactors for the future. This video is irrelevant to decision making for future nuclear energy, and thus isn't very helpful to the debate. Perhaps a more specific and informative video on the various options being pursued now as Gen IV nuclear and their SWOT analysis could replace this one.

2:55 A nuclear disaster is predicted to happen in 1925?

You can't say that a country has a lot of plutonium because they thought reprocessing was a good idea! Reprocessing is the process of removing the Plutonium (a 'byproduct' of fusion reactors, it is formed from 238U (the more abundant uranium isotope that doesn't work as fuel) is in a neutron rich environment) and then processing it to be used as fuel, you therefore end up with LESS plutonium when you reprocess.

Completely unrelated but interesting fact: the first nuclear reactors on Earth were a natural phenomenon, look up Oklo. A couple billion years ago the natural concentration of 235U was high enough that a uranium vein with water running through reached criticality (that's what it's called when a nuclear reaction becomes self-sustaining) and began to produce heat. This heat eventually boiled the water and it erupted like a geyser which in turn stopped the reaction for a time (because that natural reactor needed the water as a moderator* like many modern reactors do) until the water flowed back in and started the process over again.

*a moderator is any substance used to slow down the neutrons being emitted by the nuclear fuel. Neutrons emitted by the fuel are initially actually moving too fast to cause fission of other atoms of fuel in so called thermal reactors, so the neutrons are made to travel through the moderator, as they do they bounce off the atoms of the moderator and lose some energy until they reach an energy state (speed) called the thermal region.

The spent fuel actually can be used in different reactor designs with little reprocessing. Meltdowns are non-issues (physically impossible) with many advanced reactor designs, and proliferation isn't an issue because many advanced reactors don't make transuranics--the stuff of bombs. In fact, there are designs that don't even use uranium.

If we only made airplanes that were unsafe to fly, nobody would fly, and airplanes would be seen as not essential. But the problem of global travel is well understood, and so investing in safer aircraft design made sense. Here, the energy crisis is poorly understood, and the possible energy generation systems are also poorly understood by the general public. Therefore, while the need is as or more pressing than safe flight, the powers that be are unwilling to invest in better, safer, and more practical reactor designs.

None of these reasons are due to the inherent nature of the technology. We took a design made for ocean use (in ships and subs) and put it on land, where we spend most of our time convincing it that it's still at sea. Just as you wouldn't use a cargo plane for commercial flight, it it equally silly to insist that we have to use light water reactors on land--a place that they are inherently not designed for.

If you study the energy situation, it quickly becomes obvious that nuclear is one of the most powerful and valuable technologies with very low risks--for comparison, while thousands might have been killed by radiation released, millions are definitely killed by the by-products of the fossil fuels used, and the radiation release from those, especially coal, is orders of magnitude higher than from nuclear power. Other forms of clean energy produce variable and relatively small amounts of power, making them impractical for large-scale generation. Really, only nuclear, fossil fuel, geothermal, and hydroelectric generation produces significant amounts of power for baseline use without significant land use (which is even arguable for hydro).

Kurzgesagt, would you do a video on power generation and the current energy situation (how much is used, how its produced, etc) to put the different technologies in perspective to each other? That would also make a great video: pros and cons of various sources: wind (cons include massive pollution to refine the neodymium, frequent gear-box services, variable output, etc), solar (cons: not viable without subsidies, panels break down, pollution in manufacturing, variable output, etc), fossil fuels (cons: high radiation, toxin release plus greenhouse gasses, etc), dams (cons: changing ecosystems and environments), etc? You did a good job presenting both sides of nuclear--I'd like to see alternative systems receive the same treatment.

This video is irresponsible. Just because there has been an accident every 30 years or so with older technology doesn't mean we can expect an accident every 30 years with modern reactor technology. Any nuclear engineer worth their salt can tell you exactly what the dangers are with older reactor designs, and those concerns have been addressed in modern reactor designs. As good as your videos are, I'm disappointed that you didn't address this or factor it into your video in any way. That you made a "pro" video doesn't excuse the irresponsible nature of this video in any way.

there is one very important point you've missed in your videos though.. the cost..

While producing a plant isn't really cheap, the exploitation cost is relatively low, that's how in France for instance we were allowed very cheap electricity, with low carbon foot print for generations..

but that was VERY missleading.. now like you mentionned most of those plants reached their end of lifespan.. and we have two choices: expend them, or close them to switch to other energy.

the issue here is: BOTH are fucking expensive.. We can't switch it off and let it be, closing a plant haven't been properly funded (or funded at ALL for that matter).. and expending them would mean a massive cost for a very limited expansion (and we'd still be working with a 50+y old reactors prone to disaster.. AND the closing up cost will still be at the end of the road!
So basically no matter our choices now we'll have to pay an efty price for what's to come, and the price rise will hurt a lot no matter what.. so yeah the price we're paying now isn't the right price at all, we've been living a dream and will have to wake up with a slap in the face, and that's never fun

basically for france alone we'll have to invest 50b € to expand the current plants to 60+ years.. which is ludicrous whereas you're pro or con nuclear energy, the cost is massive for such a little gain.. can you imagine how many solar/wind/tidal plant we could create with that kind of money?

well I've run the numbers and with those 50b€ we could create at the very least 22 solar plant powering up 580MW each.. sure it won't replace the whole parc, but those facilities would be brand NEW, safe and easy to build and run, and would last way longer than those fixes we're planning to put on the old plants we have.

and what I just mentioned was only the cost to update the current plants to keep them running for a little longer (granted they ARE validated by the authorities.. which isn't 100% sure, it has to be checked plant per plant, some might not go through the tests).. then will still come the closing up cost.. official numbers (probably bottom prices, if things goes wrong it can go higher but still..) 123B€ to close up europe's plants up to 2050.. PLUS the toxic waste management.. which funnily enough is higher than the closing cost: 130B€..

So to sum it up, just to have nuclear energy up to 2050 europe need to invest 123B€+130B€ to close them up.. I mentioned france plan to use 50B just to keep them running that far.. so you can add up UK, italy etc that will probably do the same and you get over 400b€ easily..

Like I said you can think what you want about nuclear energy but facts are facts: it costs a fortune in the end, if people would have to pay the real price of nuclear they would probably change their mind about it.. but that will come sooner than later for obvious reason.

Also all that money wasted into it WON'T go to clean energy, meaning we'll have to invest more money to replace our plants ANYWAY, whereas we choose to be new nuclear power plants or solar, wind, whatever..
Good to mention also that unlike the video said thorium seem to be the future of nuclear energy.. well maybe, but that's not before the end of this century, by then I'm pretty sure we'll either be fucked up by climate change, or we would have found a way around it already, meaning those plants will just arrive after the war... Because our 70's plants are for the most part already planned to be switched with new nuclear ones, the new EPR NM plants.. which is basically the same as the 70's ones, just a bit more efficient.. IF they ever work, because as a matter of fact we're investing so much money and we've never made it work so far! (no joke, look it up)

Over the years I've come from pro nuclear 100% to let's have a mix of both, to let's use our current nuclear plants for our transition and invest in a few new plants to be the bottom part of our mix (those can run 24/7 and emits close to no CO²).
and maybe one day have the fusion plants take over and solve all our problems..

bottom line: save up energy, it's our best hope for the future

For all you dummies who say 'dump it on the moon', 'in space' or 'in the sun', that assumes a rocket never disintegrates during take off, which as we've seen, occurs regularly.

A rocket exploding carrying a heavy payload of radioactive waste would be akin to a high attitude nuclear bomb being detonated. And assuming it occurred in the upper atmosphere in the Jet Stream, it would quickly cover a large portion of the earth.

Not to mention rocket flights are expensive, and you'd need enough fuel to clear the large orbit and gravitational pull of earth (launching a satellite to geosynchronous orbit takes less fuel than if you had to escape earth's gravity into deep space). If it got stuck in orbit, then you'd just be creating a radiation problem for future astronauts, and cleaning up radiation in space is even harder.

Best solution? Don't produce any radioactive waste at all!

We don't have a proper system of treatment for it, and we're capable of reversing CO2 (not that it's pollutant unless you want to kill yourselves for 'polluting' earth with your CO2 laden breath). Renewables, and better investment in the R&D of not just energy capture, but also storage AND efficiency.

One thing we cannot sustain is this modern era of mass electrical consumption. Unless we want this planet littered with nuclear reactors, we need to make our own energy usage efficient. Of course, that means bad news if you're an energy supplier who profits off of people using electricity, so we will never see that as a valid suggestion.

I would like to correct something there. When you say that only one country is serious about long term waste management, its not true. France is also extremely serious about it too. The reason why Finland's project is more advance is mostly because when the solution was proposed in France, the parliament and the nuclear regulator stated that this solution should be experimented upon first, for at least 20 years. This was done in a dedicated laboratory. This experimentation is now almost over, and the parliament authorized the construction of the depository complex. A test phase should start in 2020, and exploitation should last for a century. The French project differs from the Finnish one because the French decided that this depository should be reversible. Should we develop a method to get rid of the waste in a more elegant way, this project is design so that we can recover the containers that were buried. The Finnish system however, is a permanent one. No solution is provided to extract the wast once it is buried. Other countries are also considering underground depository, such as Japan, the US and Switzerland. But those projects, to my knowledge, are lagging behind.

The video mentioned that we ususally don't use Plutonium as fuel, because the reactor design does not fit. However MOX(mixed oxide fuel, fuel that use plutonium) is used in 30 reactors in Europe. And it is technically possible for thermal reactors to use MOX for fuel. France, which has extensive  reprocessing capability even though it does not have the incentive to build large stockpiles of nuclear weapons. France plans to have MOX fuel used in many reactors. Also Japan, a signatory of the NPT has significant reprocessing capability and used some of their pluotnium for fuel. Japan is not deemed a country pocessing nuclear weapons, but has reprocessing capability. Therefore it can be said that reprocessing and nuclear weapons does not come 'hand in hand' together. Also there are cases of MOX fuel used for conventional light water reactors, unlike what is mentioned in the video.

I think the whole nuclear war crisis scare ended a long time ago. Guys, the Cold War is over, we can stop freaking out about nuclear weapons and how they're the biggest problem ever. Last I remember, only two nukes have ever been used in warfare, and both were used by the United States. You know, the guys who are more freaked out than anyone else about them. Given how few have actually been used to kill people, I think we all understand that the threat of what they can do is deterrent enough to keep anyone from actually using them ever again. Regardless of whether you support countries keeping that tech ready to go, the weapons exist, the technology exists, and they aren't going anywhere even if we shut down nuclear plants. So yeah, the 'they make scary weapons' part doesn't hold much water as an argument against nuclear power.

Also, look at the nuclear disasters that happened. Almost all of them occurred with older, less safe technology. We've improved our safety regulations for nuclear plants to the point where it is next to impossible for a Chernobyl style disaster to happen ever again. The Fukushima disaster is a case of containment being severely tested, and it is cause for further improvements in the technology and safety regulations to prevent it happening again.

The fact is, nuclear is much safer than most people think. The risk of accidents is low, it's greatly declined since most of the accidents on record and it continues to decline. The damage done is generally overestimated, and the likelihood we'll see that we'll see many major nuclear disasters again in the future is low. The assertion that we'll see one every 10 years or so is frankly absurd and based on outdated data.

I'm fine with the bias of this video in general towards the dangers of nuclear waste and nuclear weapons and I agree entirely that these are problems that must be solved. But the link between nuclear power and nuclear weapons is purely imaginary, not physical, and no amount of bias can really justify attempts to link the two.

The core issue is that you cannot use waste-grade plutonium in nuclear weapons. Yes, as of writing, YOU CAN NOT PHYSICALLY DO IT, NO TECHNOLOGY OR THEORETICAL METHOD CONCEIVABLE ALLOWS YOU TO SUSTAIN A NUCLEAR CHAIN REACTION IN THE FAST NEUTRON SPECTRUM WITH PLUTONIUM CONTAINING OVER 20% PU-240!!! It simply contains too much Pu-240 and as a result its critical mass approaches INFINITY for the fast-neutron spectrum that nuclear weapons utilize. You are not even dealing with a very slight "maybe it's possible", you are dealing with "no, it is completely absolutely utterly impossible and it makes just as much sense as claiming 1 + 1 = 5".

Now, maybe, and this is a very big maybe, we will find a way to separate Pu-239 (the fuel isotope) from Pu-240 (the problem isotope) in the distant future, using technology that supersedes the effectiveness of current enrichment by several orders of magnitude. But this is effectively converting waste-grade plutonium to weapons-grade (you are not using waste-grade plutonium directly in a bomb, because again this is IMPOSSIBLE TO DO), and even then there will be absolutely no sensible way to justify producing weapons-grade plutonium via this route because it will always be easier, faster, and more efficient to enrich uranium, or just produce very pure plutonium to begin with.

The grey horse is reactor-grade plutonium, produced as a "waste" product from certain specialized reactors, but mostly produced from low-burnup cycling in heavy water reactors and in research reactors. It is called 'reactor grade" because it can support a nuclear fission chain reaction under the right circumstances, but usually these circumstances are long burnup and slow reaction propagation, with both cases being the polar opposites of what nuclear weapons need to favor. In the future, if we ever develop the Gen IV reactors that operate on the plutonium cycle, we will likely be mixing weapons grade plutonium with waste grade plutonium to produce this sort of in-between plutonium, ideal for fueling those reactors but far less useful for fueling weapons. That said, you can use reactor-grade plutonium in weapons and this has been done a few times before, but the yield and reliability of the weapon is mediocre at best and decreases exponentially as you approach 20% Pu-240. And, most importantly, you still need to develop the necessary implosion technology, which is arguably the most difficult part of building plutonium bombs to begin with. Because of this, only a few nuclear weapons in human history have utilized reactor-grade plutonium and these were strictly delegated to tests, resulting in mediocre weapon yield at best (see US-UK test using plutonium from a Magnox reactor in the late 60s) and a complete dud at worst (see most recent Korean weapon test that "fizzled"). Reactor-grade plutonium production across a fleet of nuclear power plants is also much slower than simply dedicating a couple reactors entirely towards producing weapons-grade plutonium, and would produce far less energy than dedicated power plant reactors, so why even bother?

Without even watching this video, I have my own reasons for thinking about fission nuclear energy as being terrible.  My main problem with fission nuclear energy is that it simply has too many risks to justify its perceived benefits.  Just look at what happened at Chernobyl and what nearly happened at Three Mile Island long before that.  Secondly, I believe that even if the risks could be contained, we lack the discipline to properly maintain our fission nuclear technology, as evidenced by the fact that some fission nuclear power plants aren't even safe to begin with due to their shoddy construction.  Maybe fission nuclear plants could be built on a much smaller scale to reduce the risk of contamination if one of them blows up.  Maybe they could be built on floating modules out in the ocean with long, thick wires taking their power to shore.  But even if those things were possible, I still don't know how well they would work because no matter how you cut it, fission nuclear energy is potentially dangerous to everything around it, including the atmosphere itself.  If we have to use nuclear energy, we should use fusion nuclear energy instead of fission nuclear energy, even if we have to wait for years for fusion nuclear energy to be practical.

Uranium for medical research and power plant use has to be enriched from 3% to 20%, according to the IAEA (International Atomic Energy Agency). 90% enrichment is required for use in weapons. The steps of enriching are adding turbines and increasing the efficiency of turbines, which take up massive amounts of space. A nuclear factory that is illegally producing or procuring nuclear weapons would have to hide itself from the IAEA committees, the ever watchful eyes of member states that aren't allied with said proliferating country, and the global network of satellites, which are constantly scanning for the exact tell tale signs of nuclear proliferation and development.

So what that means for this video is that nuclear energy is linked, obviously, BUT it would appear that this video erroneously concludes that it is easy to hide nuclear weapons development under the guise of factory development.

I don't know about the other four catastrophes, but here's the run-down of Three-Mile Island, Chernobyl, and Fukushima.

TMI:
a partial-core meltdown, literally a worst-case scenario for the plant. Human error actually made it worst than it could have been, since instead of sending more water into the reactor, they misinterpreted the errors and reduced water flow. TMI originated with a problem in the water delivery system.

Chernobyl:
I don't know as much about Chernobyl as TMI, but I do know that the constructors of Chernobyl had some disregard for safety. Not terribly surprising considering the fact that it was part of the USSR.

Fukushima:
Why on Earth would you build a nuclear power plant on the most notoriously tsunami-prone coast in the world??? You'd think they would have instead built it in the mountains, or on the other coast, where there aren't as many tsunamis.

People, do some research - haven't any of you heard of Gen IV reactors? For example, the Integral Molten Salt Reactor or IMSR (made in Canada) is a completely different kind of reactor which:
1. Cannot melt down, as the fuel/salt mix is already in a molten state
2. Creates extremely small amounts of waste, which are only radioactive for a couple hundred years (instead of 20,000!)
3. Can use spent Uranium as a fuel - or Thorium, which is as plentiful as lead, and safe enough to hold in your hand
4. Does not create usable bomb-making material (Plutonium) - so no proliferation problems
5. Is much smaller and less expensive than the huge outdated reactors in use all over the place

... and many many more benefits

If you used a Light Water Reactor to make bombs it would be very obvious. Your plant's capacity factor would be less than 50% compared to 90% of normal operation. This is because you need to get the plutonium-239 out of there before it becomes the wrong isotope (Pu-240). It takes a long time (and low burnup) to refuel to get fuel rods with optimal Pu content out. Weapons grade plutonium is almost always made in a military reactor because of this.

An 85% fissile plutonium bomb is possible but substandard, any lower and you'd probably get a fissile or a dud.

What about nuclear fusion? The half life of the nuclear waste is only a few decades, and most of the waste is the worn out parts of the reactor itself.

Additionally, a fusion reactor cannot meltdown because it requires a vacuum for the reaction to exist. So any breach would inherently shut it down.

Obviously, practical fusion energy is, even in the most extremely optimistic projections, at least a decade away. But it will be much safer, more efficient, and infinitely more environmentally friendly. Plus! You can't synthesize fissionable materials using the technology.

And to any morons who may say "what about fusion bombs?," it requires an atom bomb to set off the fusion reaction in a fusion bomb. So no atom bomb, no boom.

Every single "fact" presented in this video is either due to fearmongering or obsolete reactor designs.

- The number of people killed by Fukushima is zero.
- The number of people killed by Three Mile Island is zero.
- The number of people experiencing radiation sickness from both Three Mile Island and Fukushima is zero.
- The number of people injured by radiation in TMI and Fukushima who were not directly involved in cleanup or repair operations is zero.
- The number of people killed by Chernobyl is less than one thousand, and it is nearly impossible to determine if those who died from cancer died due the accident. In addition, the main cancers that would be expected due to fallout exposure are highly treatable. 
- The Chernobyl exclusion zone has become a nearly pristine nature preserve now that humans aren't there polluting it anymore.
- The Fukushima exclusion zone is due purely to fear-mongering, as the statistical increase in expected cancers living right up to the gates of the plant is negligible. 
- The Fukushima accident was only upgraded to INES-7 due to political pressure from ignorant environmentalists. It meets none of the criteria or guidelines specified by the IEA for being classified as a level 7 event.
- There are multiple places in the world with natural radiation levels above those of Fukushima and Chernobyl, whose cancer rates are shown in some cases to be LESS than those of areas with lower background radiation.

- Currently operating civilian reactors are nothing more than scaled up military designs, which is why there is any weapons proliferation concern at all. 
- Currently operating civilian reactor designs are well over half a century old, which is why they have any kind of accident danger at all. How much do you think technology has progressed since the 1950s?
- Currently operating civilian reactor designs are the reason there is any long-lived nuclear waste at all. Bowever, that waste can be reburned in newer and older designs and essentially rendered harmless. It is due to an executive order by President Carter that the United States does not reprocess waste and reburn it in reactors. This executive order came from ignorant environmentalist pressure as well as those advocating nuclear disarmament. 
- Ignorant environmentalists spewing "radiation as a boogey-man" propaganda is the reason we're stuck with these old designs, as it is impossible for any replacement designs to get traction due to all of the government red tape and public fear.
- Plutonium's toxicity is greatly exaggerated. Chemically it is roughly as toxic as lead. Radiologically plutonium must be ingested to present a significant hazard for most isotopes. 
- Modern, safer reactor designs can be built that do not produce or require plutonium or uranium and result in waste products that only last roughly 200 years. However, once again pressure from environmentalists is preventing this progress.
- Both wind and solar require far nastier chemicals used in their construction than the construction of a modern nuclear power plant design, are far more expensive, and in the case of wind, far more environmentally destructive. Solar is highly inefficient and would require vast areas of land to produce enough energy to satisfy a medium sized city.

I'm all for SAFE nuclear energy but I have to agree that current technology is pretty terrible.  Thorium shows promise but it's really nuclear fusion that has my attention.  The two isotopes of hydrogen, deuterium and tritium, that are used as fuel are super-easy to acquire and the closest thing to waste that fusion reactors can produce are discarded reactor components.  Only problem is that fusion reactors are likely much farther away from becoming practical than the ones that will run on thorium, but I'm optimistic.

I feel like you have really misrepresented these issues with nuclear energy.

1. Nuclear weapons. We already have nuclear weapon technology and we already have enough nuclear weapons to destroy the earth many times over. We are not going to create more nuclear weapons because we are using nuclear energy

2. Nuclear waste. Pretty spot on but is manageable. Nuclear waste is very small and although a ton sounds like a lot it can fit in a small area. Current generation reactors also produce much less waste than old reactors and so we won't be adding as much as you might think.

3. Nuclear disasters. All nuclear disasters in the past has been due to old reactors and lack of legislation requiring maintenance/security measures. In the US and most of Europe we have legislation enforcing maintenance and security measures (arguably too much) and with current generation reactors the risk of failure is far less than the risk of damn failing or a coal plant exploding. Also the severity of a possible failure is much lower than both hydroelectric and coal/oil plants. Nuclear disasters sound scary but we are really good at mitigating their damage and avoiding them altogether.

Thank you for providing this series of videos, it has been quite interesting. 

In hopes of helping you improve in the future, there are two possible errors in this video you may wish to consider.

The first point of contention is with the statement at about 1:38 - that we lack reactors that use plutonium. 

We have been using Mixed Oxide Fuel (MOX) for decades. A key part of many treaties between Russia and the USA involves removing the pits from nuclear weapons, down-blending them with uranium, and then using up the material in civilian reactors. 

Pure plutonium fast-breeder reactors have been a possibility for a while, but few went into operation due to the changing view of nuclear power in the 70s.

A second concern is the diagram of nuclear accidents. I should also point out that Kyshtym was a weapons and materials processing center, not a power plant. This does not change the fact that it was a notable radioactive release - but it is disingenuous to include in a list of power-pant mishaps. 

Once again, thank you for your time and high production values.

Thanks a bunch for trying to make this topic understandable. I do however have one factual issue.

Why can't we dump waste in the ocean...? Water stops radiation better than almost any other material of similar price. In nuclear power-plants, they often place fresh byproducts of reactions into big ass pools for a few months as they reduce in radiation output. Those pools are usually only tens of meters deep, but the radiation measured at the surface is less than the radiation measured on a standard plane flight at 30km altitude. The oceans are around 4 to 6 kilometers deep in most places, and there are some areas of the ocean floor where no large animals would get within a few meters of the waste and die.

Where Did Natural Background Radiation Come From?

The sum of the natural background radiation at Fukushima plus the radiation leak from the reactor is less than the natural background radiation where I live in Illinois.  There was no reason for Japan to shut down their reactors.  If the reactors at Fukushima had not been shut down, would they have continued to operate normally?

Where did natural background radiation come from?  The universe started out with only 3 elements: hydrogen, helium and lithium.  All other elements were made in stars or by supernova explosions.  Our star is a seventh generation star.  The previous 6 generations were necessary for the elements heavier than lithium to be built up.  Since heavier elements were built by radiation processes, they were very radioactive when first made.  

Our planet was made of the debris of a supernova explosion that happened about 5 billion years ago.  The Earth has been decreasing in radioactivity ever since.  All elements heavier than iron were necessarily made by accretion of mostly neutrons but sometimes protons onto lighter nuclei.  Radioactive decays were necessary to bring these new nuclei into the realm of nuclear stability.  That is why all rocks are still radioactive.

Radiation also comes from outer space in the form of cosmic rays.  Cosmic rays come from supernovas that are very far away.  There will always be cosmic rays.

There is no such thing as nuclear waste.   It is recyclable fuel that is being wasted.   See:

The newspaper makes the usual errors, such as calling spent reactor fuel "weapons grade" which it certainly was not.
We don't recycle nuclear fuel because it is valuable and people steal it.   The place it went that it wasn't supposed to go to was Israel.   This happened in a small town near Pittsburgh, PA circa 1970.   A company called Numec was in the business of reprocessing nuclear fuel.   I almost took a job there, designing a nuclear battery for a heart pacemaker.   [A nuclear battery would have the advantage of lasting many times as long as any other battery, eliminating many surgeries to replace batteries.]   Numec did NOT have a reactor.   Numec "lost" half a ton of spent fuel.   It wound up in Israel.   The Israelis have fueled  their nuclear power plants by stealing nuclear "waste."   It could work for any other country, such as Iran or the United States.   
It is only when you don't have access to nuclear "waste" that you have to do the difficult process of enriching uranium.   
Numec is no longer in business.   Terrorists can't compete with Mossad and Israeli dual citizens who are CEOs of companies like Numec.   Israeli nuclear weapons are exact duplicates of American nuclear weapons.   All persons who were "born of Jewish mothers" are citizens of Israel regardless of any other fact.   Since the US can't and shouldn't discriminate, the reprocessing of nuclear fuel in the US stopped.   That was the only politically possible solution at that time, given that private corporations did the reprocessing.   My solution would be to reprocess the fuel at a Government Owned Government Operated [GOGO] facility.   At a GOGO plant, bureaucracy and the multiplicity of ethnicity and religion would disable the transportation of uranium to Israel or to any unauthorized place.   Nothing heavier than a secret would get out.

NOTE:  THE SOURCE OF "FUEL" FOR THE HEART PACEMAKER BATTERY WAS SPENT REACTOR FUEL.   Nuclear heart pacemakers were sold and implanted in living human heart patients, but they were expensive.   Other uses for radioactive elements from spent fuel:  cancer treatment, such as radioactive "grains" to put in your cancerous prostate.

Why a Nuclear Powerplant CAN NOT Explode like a Nuclear Bomb: 
A nuclear bomb "compresses" pure or nearly pure fissile material into a small space. The fissile material is either the uranium235 or plutonium239. They are the reduced bright shiny metals, not metal oxide. If it is uranium, it is at least 20% and preferably  90% uranium235 and 10% or less uranium238.  These fissile materials are metals and very difficult to compress. Because they are difficult to compress, a high explosive is required to compress them. Pieces of the fissile material have to slam into each other hard for the nuclear reactions to take place. 
A nuclear reactor, such as the ones used for power generation, does not have any pure fissile material. The fuel may be 0.7% to 8% uranium235 oxide mixed with uranium238 oxide [uranium rust]. A mixture of 0.7% to 8% uranium235 rust mixed with uranium238 rust cannot be made to explode no matter how hard you try. A small amount of plutonium oxide mixed in with the uranium oxide can not change this.  
The fuel is further diluted by being divided and sealed into many steel capsules. The capsules are contained in steel tubes. The fuel is further diluted by the need for coolant to flow around the capsules and through the core so that heat can be transported to a place where heat energy can be converted to electrical energy.  
There has never been a NUCLEAR explosion inside a reactor and there never will be.  There was no NUCLEAR explosion at Chernobyl.

The plutonium produced by power plants is the wrong isotope to make bombs.  It is Plutonium240.  It has 1 too many neutrons and the extra neutron cannot be removed.   Bombs require Plutonium239.  Making Pu239 requires a short-cycle reactor.  A  short-cycle reactor is no good as a power plant.  Those fears of proliferation are completely unjustified.

Short cycling means turning the reactor off after a month of operation and replacing the fuel so that Pu239 can be extracted.  A normal fuel cycle is 18 to 24 months. A normal fuel cycle is long enough to convert Pu239 to Pu240 and higher isotopes.  Turning off a billion watts is very obvious.  It can't be hidden.  Replacing fuel requires a month.  Power plant [civilian] reactors cannot be used to make plutonium239 to make bombs.  Those fears of proliferation are completely unjustified.

I find it kinda misleading that you do not distinguish between nuclear accidents caused by natural disasters, and nuclear accidents caused purely by human error. Fukushima was hit by an earthquake as well as a tsunami - which caused about 18000 deaths - and it failed (at least partly) because it wasn't living up to the standards set by the Japanese government. 

The Fukushima accident bleakens in comparison to the deaths caused by the tsunami, and everyone will see how it's a totally different kind of accident compared to Chernobyl - it would never happen in a country like Germany, France, etc. that don't experience natural disasters of that scale. As you mention in the other video, the alternatives have way worse death counts. 

Calling 3 of the accidents "contained" also begs the question - how much radioactive material was emitted by the non-contained accidents? Accepting a nuclear accident every ten years doesn't mean accepting Chernobyl levels of radiation - Fukushima was around 930PBq, Chernobyl about 5200PBq, despite Fukushima having much more fuel. Three mile island emitted only about 480PBq, and Kyshtum was about 80PBq - just lumping those together as "significant amounts of radiation" completely ignores the actual scale of the accidents, even if we ignore the fact that not all radioactive material is equally dangerous (most of the TMI output is considered harmless). 

I get that you're making two videos, and each represent a different side, but doing a for/against doesn't mean you have to omit facts in either of them. You generally make really good educational videos, but personally I think this one was sub-par and oversimplified to the point of it being misleading.

1. proliferation
No commercial spent fuel has ever been used to create a bomb.
To make plutonium you need to remove the spent fuel after 2 weeks/months.
This cycle of operation, shutdown, fuel exchange is a BIG signal to satellites
that plutonium production is underway.
2. Waste.
Reprocessing is not just for plutonium, you can extract the unspent uranium
to use for fuel. The 3% remaining high level waste is a smaller volume to be
vitrified and stored/buried. The often quoted 'tens of thousands of years' means
that what little radioactivity that remains will be slight. Radioactive decay is a logarithmic curve. Out of a reactor spent fuel is perhaps 1 billion times more radioactive than uranium ore. After ten years in a cooling pool it drops a thousand fold to be a million times. After 130 years its only a thousand times.
See how the time interval is increasing, it may take 3000 years to drop to 100 times
the radioactivity of ore, but even a thousand times may not be dangerous. We really
don't know the dangers of low level radioactivity but the small amount of data from
the small number of accidents suggest the danger is highly overstated.
3. Accidents
Most of the Fukushima residents can return now, they have subsidised housing so
have little incentive to do so. Not 'unfit for human habitation for decades'.
In reality there was perhaps 2 months of dangerous iodine 131 levels and people
should have been allowed to return after that. A 'Devastating' disaster like
Fukushima, where no one dies, is certainly something I can live with every ten years.

The information in this video is terribly presented.Yes, the facts about nuclear waste and nuclear proliferation are correct.  However, when placed along side the environmental effects of fossil fuel energy, nuclear power does FAR LESS damage to the planet and the people.  We are in fact having a global climate change problem which was largely due to our fossil fuel burning throughout the decades.  The world is racing to curb fossil fuel burning for this very reason.  Indeed, BOTH technologies harm the environment but at this point in time we cannot burn more fossil fuels.  Wind/Solar energies are not sufficient at all for powering entire cities, for example.  Future-tech solutions  are many decades away, at least.  The information presented in this video does more harm than it does educate!  Case in point: The image at 3:14 shows black smoke out of the cooling towers.  Nuclear power plants ONLY toxic waste is in the spent fuel; the towers release ONLY steam, pure H20 and nothing more.  Our energy needs are becoming a problem, but we need to clearly weigh all options equally and not present weakly researched and badly transmitted information as such is done in this video.  Very disappointing Kurz Gesagt.
